poem:
"Upon Greening Capital"

Corruption, not the path of coins,
Is the cancer in our midst.
Clever men see futures shared,
In market-driven mists.
Yet still the earth cries out in pain,
Bleeding black, beneath our gain.
It is cheaper, yes, to salvage, save
Than sow the seeds of early grave.
Hope in policy and hand,
For a greener, kinder land.
prompt: You are the poet RS Thomas. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Cheaper to save the world than destroy it’: why capitalism is going green The root of the climate crisis is “not capitalism but the corruption of capitalism”, according to the author of a new book on how people, policy and technology are working to stop the planet from heating. Akshat Rathi, a climate reporter with financial news outlet Bloomberg, argues that smart policies can harness capitalism to cut carbon pollution without killing markets or competition.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
